Description: Body sherd with turn to rim of East Greek, probably Aeolian, grey ware pottery dinos; interior: reserved; exterior: very dark worn slip and inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: According to Gardner (1888, p. 47, pl. XXI no. 791), the sherd was excavated in the Sanctuary of Aphrodite but the modern inscription 'DERA' (sic) incised on the interior surface points to the sherd having been found in the Sanctuary of Hera or Dioskouroi. Gardner (1888 p. 47) suggests that the vessel probably originated from Mytilene or Lesbos because of the dialect of the inscription on the sherd. The fabric finds parallels with British Museum 1888,0601.637 which was analysed with NAA by Hans Mommsen (Bonn). The results placed the fabric (sample NAUK 64) in NAA group G and the origin was determined to be Aeolis.
Fabric, varying thickness and letter forms suggest that British Museum1965,0930.429 is from the same piece.
Bibliographic references: Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II (p. 65, no. 791, pl. XXI, no. 791)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 686, no. 442, pl. 22)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GL.039)
